Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls, sounding very upset, and asks if you have a moment to talk about a recent argument with their partner.
Situation2: They must follow strict procedures for a large cash deposit at the end of a busy shift to comply with corporate auditing rules.
Story: The store was finally quiet after a long, hectic shift. I was counting the cash for the end-of-day deposit, double-checking every bill and coin, when my phone buzzed. It was my friend, Sam. I hesitated, but answered. Sam’s voice trembled, “Can you talk? I just had a huge fight with Jamie. I really need you right now.” My heart twisted—I could hear how much Sam needed me to listen, to be there, to offer comfort. But the register drawer was open, and the deposit log was only half-filled. I knew the rules: no distractions, no mistakes, or I could get written up, maybe even lose my job. My manager had drilled it into us—follow every step, no exceptions. I looked at the clock, feeling the pressure of the store’s closing routine and Sam’s pain on the other end of the line. My hands shook as I held the phone, torn between being the friend Sam needed and the responsible cashier my job demanded.
